Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Legal Regulatory Regimes and Small-Scale Business Productivity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Small-scale businesses have long been viewed as crucial to community livelihoods. They constitute the largest block of employers, are significant in creating new jobs in growth industries, and are critical for diversifying the local economy. Artisanal production in particular has been identified as an important channel for economic revitalization in areas afflicted by increased unemployment and declines in the agricultural and industrial sectors. But they face challenges when entering larger regional and global markets. Existing research on artisanal economies has long debated whether artisanal production can remain separate from processes of mass production as their popularity increases in global markets. It is not clear what influence legal property certifications, such as a geographic indication (GI) and origin trademarks, are having in expanding and protecting market access for new businesses. This research project, which trains a student in the methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, explores what impact introductory legal regulatory regimes have on the productive capacity of small-scale enterprises. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology, findings will be disseminated to aid organizations that explore and manage the causes, consequences, and complexities of intellectual and cultural property.

Aditi Halbe, under the supervision of Dr. Akhil Gupta of the University of California, Los Angeles, will explore the impact of legal property certifications on artisanal production. This research will be conducted in Kachchh district of India's third largest industrialized state, Gujarat. Home to many artisan communities that make traditional crafts as their primary means of livelihood, Kachchh experienced a 7.7 magnitude earthquake in 2001 that devastated community livelihoods. Following the earthquake, development organizations, social enterprises, and government programs helped reengage and expand markets for traditional crafts, reaffirming the importance of artisanal production. Kachchh is thus uniquely situated to understanding how daily practices of artisanal production intersect with larger development agendas, attuned to livelihood concerns in the face of current, social, ecological and political uncertainties. Focusing on collaborations between artisans and designers to innovate products for international markets, the research will examine how artisans negotiate the demands of global consumers through adjustments to everyday processes of traditional craft production. Methods include traditional ethnographic data collection techniques such as participant observation, in-depth semi-structured interviews, and oral histories with artisan producers and stakeholders, development workers, and for-profit organizations. Attending to the authentication and regulation of these products through legal cultural property designations like origin trademarks and geographic indication, this research will analyze the institutional mechanisms by which economic development strategies are enacted upon small-scale artisanal producers. The research findings will address how artisanal producers and consumers envision and negotiate their relationship within the global market.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aditi Halbe has completed her dissertation research, “Legal Regulatory Regimes and Small Scale Business Productivity,” which was supported by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research grant. During her funding period she spent one year working with craft NGOs and the traditional weaving community in Kachchh, Gujarat, a district devastated by a 7.7 magnitude earthquake in 2001. As a socio-cultural anthropologist, she was interested in the ways in which development organizations, social enterprises and government programs reengaged and expanded markets for traditional crafts after the earthquake destroyed many artisan communities’ primary means of livelihood. Her dissertation research focused on the ways in which artisan producers articulate economic development strategies and use legal regulatory regimes like origin trademarks to access global markets.

Through participant observation and interviews conducted with interlocutors who worked within the development sector, the weaving community as well as scholars and activists working in the craft sector, Halbe was able to maps social, economic and technological changes in Kachchhi weaving and situate the ways in which the logic of entrepreneurship had come to be deeply rooted in the implementation of development initiatives. While the use legal regulatory remiges extended this logic, it was not the primary means by which artisans negotiated the challenges of expanding market access. Instead, ideas of ‘good design’ and innovationwere crucial to enlarging trade and expanding the circulation of hand crafted textiles. Branded as small-batch, hand-crafted, local and sustainable, these products relied on marketing strategies that authenticated producers’ labor, locating them as members of a traditional community and pointing to the traditional knowledge contained in craft making, outside legal regimes of regulation. 

Considering the impact of on-the-ground shifts in artisan production processes, as well as contracts and negotiations between artisans and designers, in formulating narratives about cultural property that circulate within global artisanal markets, Halbe interrogated the big business of artisan production. She found that the emphasis on design and creativity, important in marking an artisan, both within the community and in global markets, obscured the diversity of business and collaboration models that artisans mobilize. She argues that an analysis of these models provides insights into the conditions of informality and precarity of artisan production, as well as aspirations of development amongst the weaving community that otherwise remain unrecognized. 

Artisanal production has increasingly become a conduit for economic revitalization and community livelihoods in places where industrialization is increasing and where employment and agricultural activity are declining. A center of internationally and nationally renowned craft traditions, Kachchh, India’s largest district located in India’s third largest industrialized state, Gujarat presents a microcosm of the anxieties surrounding Indian development as traditional craft is the primary means of livelihood for many Kachchhi artisan communities.Kachchh is thus uniquely situated to understanding how daily practices of artisanal production intersect with larger development agendas, attuned to livelihood concerns in the face of current, social, ecological and political uncertainties.
